audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker introducing a video about APA style formatting in Microsoft Word on Macintosh operating systems. The speaker provides a brief statement about the version of the APA publication manual that the video pertains to. We hear a mouse click sound followed by the speaker describing how to manipulate the Word window on the screen, including how to adjust the size and zoom.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing the interface of a program similar to Microsoft Word, pointing out the ribbon feature for menu organization and mentioning the Home tab. He then notes that all menu options can also be found in the bar at the top of the screen.

The audio begins with a male speaker providing instructions on formatting a template for APA style, speaking in a neutral tone. He instructs the listener to "click on file" and then "page setup." He explains how to find the "page setup options" and set the margins to one inch. He mentions setting the header and footer, and then "layout options."

The audio clip begins with a single speaker, sounding informative, describing how to format a document in APA style, specifically regarding headers and margins on the first page, suggesting to save the setting as default for future use. There is no audible background music, sounds, or environmental noises.

The audio clip features one male speaker explaining how to adjust margins by hovering over the edge until it looks like two arrows. He explains that text can be typed independently of the margins and that you can control where it appears by moving the arrows. To control the text settings with more precision, he instructs the listener to go to the top menu bar and click on format, then font.

The audio clip features a single male speaker providing instructions about APA style formatting. His tone is informative and instructional, mentioning "Times New Roman 12-point font" and "spacing and indentation."

The audio clip features a single speaker with a neutral tone, stating formatting instructions for APA style, including paragraph alignment, indentation, double spacing, and avoiding extra spaces. The speech transitions to indicate the conclusion of the described details.

The clip begins with a male speaker providing instructions to uncheck the "Widow Orphan Control" option in document formatting settings, warning that it can lead to unnecessary spacing. Next, he instructs the listener to insert a header by navigating through a top menu.

The clip begins with a male speaker describing a new tab appearing in the ribbon at the top of the window to control options. He continues, noting you can "move between the header and the text". He then explains how in the "header footer tab" you can "click on page number to insert automatic page numbers". Finally, the clip ends with a male speaker saying "Alright".

The clip begins with speech. One person is speaking with an instructional tone. The speaker describes writing the phrase "running head" and adding a colon to the left of a page number within a header. The speaker instructs the listener to utilize the tab key and align the tab marker to the right margin. The speaker then advises choosing keywords from the title of the paper for an abbreviated header and to type them in capital letters. The clip ends with a short sound that may be described as a ding.

The clip begins with a male speaker offering instruction, advising the listener to double-click within the body of text, hit enter several times, and then start writing the title. He instructs that the title should capitalize the first word as well as all major words, making sure that it is centered. Next he specifies that APA style includes nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, and adverbs, along with any four-or-more-letter conjunctions and prepositions. He then instructs to type the name below the title, followed by the university or institution name. The clip concludes with a reverberating sound effect of a bell ringing.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker, methodically walking through steps related to a digital document by, for example, going to the top menu, selecting insert, and then "break, page break." He is speaking in a calm, instructive tone, mentioning ensuring labels on the next page appear correctly, centering the word "abstract," and inserting another page break. He suggests copying the title from the first page to ensure consistency. The speaker then mentions setting text flush left with first-line indentation, explaining that the abstract is the only paragraph not indented.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining how to insert a header on additional pages. He instructs to copy the header and page number, but not the words "running head," from the first page, and paste it onto subsequent pages. He notes that the page numbers will be automatic and specifies Times New Roman 12-point font. He also points out that the header should be flush left, and the page number, flush right.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker outlining formatting guidelines for a text document, specifically mentioning "all sections of the main text are continuous." His tone is instructional. He instructs the listener to remove indentation and center the word "references" at the top of the page. He continues with instructions on setting hanging indentation, suggesting using the ruler or formatting options. He concludes by advising to "consult the APA manual" for further details. He then utters a sound similar to speech, but it lacks discernible context, resembling a filler or affirmation like "yeah" or "yep".

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the use of an "n-dash" in APA style when referring to "a range of numbers." He explains how to insert one by going to the insert menu, symbol, advanced symbol, and then selecting "special characters." He demonstrates the current keyboard shortcut and describes how to create a new one, suggesting holding command and pressing the regular hyphen. Finally, a distinct sound akin to that of "a" or "the" is heard at the conclusion.

The audio starts with a question about the size difference between a regular hyphen, an en dash, and an em dash, followed by a description emphasizing their specific purpose in APA style and the importance of using the right one. Next, an explanation is provided on manually creating an en dash, describing the process of typing page numbers, hyphens, and spaces, followed by a period or space that converts the hyphen to an en dash, with a reminder to remove the spaces afterwards. The audio ends abruptly with a sound that could be a click.

The clip starts with a male speaker providing advice on learning new programs, suggesting instructional videos from Apple or Microsoft, Google searches, and, most importantly, hands-on experimentation. He notes additional resources for APA formatting, such as the Kennesaw State Psychology Lab webpage or the APA Publication Manual. He concludes by thanking the audience.
